quest_title: If the lengths of the sides of a triangle are 3, 5, 7, then the largest angle of the triangle is
explanation_txt:
Let sides of triangle \( a , b , c \) are respectively 3, 5 and 7.

\(\begin{array} { l } { \therefore \cos C = \cfrac { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } - c ^ { 2 } } { 2 a b } = \cfrac { 9 + 25 - 49 } { 2 \times 3 \times 5 } = \cfrac { - 15 } { 30 } = - \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } } \\ { \angle C = \cfrac { 2 \pi } { 3 } ( \text { largest angle } ) } \end{array}\)

explanation_plain_text: Let sides of triangle are respectively 3, 5 and 7.

quest_title: \[\lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { ( a + h ) ^ { 2 } \sin ( a + h ) - a ^ { 2 } \sin a } { h } =\]
explanation_txt:
This is definition of derivative of \( a^2 \sin a \).

\( \cfrac { d } { d a } \left[ a ^ { 2 } \sin a \right] =2 a \sin a + a ^ { 2 } \cos a\)

OR,

Using L-Hopital Rule:

\[\begin{align} \lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { ( a + h ) ^ { 2 } \sin ( a + h ) - a ^ { 2 } \sin a } { h } & = \lim _ { h \rightarrow 0 } \cfrac { 2 ( a + h ) \sin ( a + h ) + ( a + h ) ^ { 2 } \cos ( a + h ) } { 1 } \\ & = 2 a \sin a + a ^ { 2 } \cos a \end{align}\]
explanation_plain_text:
This is definition of derivative of .

OR,

Using L-Hopital Rule:

quest_title: If the path of a moving point is the curve \(x = a t , y = b \sin a t \) , then its acceleration at any instant
ans1_txt: Varies as the distance from the axis of y
ans2_txt: Varies as the distance of the point from the origin
ans4_txt: Varies as the distance from the axis of x
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \cfrac { d x } { d t } = v _ { x } = a \Rightarrow \cfrac { d ^ { 2 } x } { d t ^ { 2 } } = 0 = a _ { x } } \\ { a _ { x } \text { is acceleration in } x \text { -axis } } \\ { \cfrac { d ^ { 2 } y } { d t ^ { 2 } } = - b a ^ { 2 } \sin a t \Rightarrow a _ { y } = - a ^ { 2 } y } \\ { \text { Hence, } a _ { y } \text { changes as } y \text { changes. } } \end{array}\)
question_plain_title: If the path of a moving point is the curve , then its acceleration at any instant
ans1_plain_text: Varies as the distance from the axis of y
ans2_plain_text: Varies as the distance of the point from the origin
ans4_plain_text: Varies as the distance from the axis of x

quest_title: A projectile has the maximum range of 500 m. If the projectile is now thrown up an inclined plane of 30\(^{\circ}\) with same speed, the distance covered by it along the plane is
explanation_txt:
\(R=\cfrac{u^{2}}{g} \)
\(\therefore u=\sqrt{500 \times 10} \)
For inclined plane,
\(V^{2}=u^{2}-2 g \sin 30^{\circ} \times l \)

\(\text { or, } 0=5000-2 \times 10 \times \cfrac{1}{2} \times l \)
\(\therefore l=500 \mathrm{m} \)

quest_title: Three point charges \({q}\), \({q}\) and -\({q}\) are placed at the corners of an equilateral triangle of side \({a}\). Another charge \({Q}\) is kept at the centroid. Force exerted on \({Q}\) is:
explanation_txt:
Distance from charge \(-q\) to charge \(Q\) is
\(r=\cfrac{q}{\sqrt{3}}\)
Force acted by two charges \(q\) on charge \(Q\) is \(F\) and their resultant:
\(R=\sqrt{F^{2}+F^{2}+2 F F \cos 120}=F\)
Also, force applied by \(-q\) on \(Q\) is \(F\)
So, net force
\(\begin{array}{l}{F^{\prime}=F+F=2 F} \\ {F^{\prime}=F+F}\end{array}\)
\( F^{\prime} =2 \times \cfrac{q Q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}\left(\cfrac{q}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{2}} \\ \therefore \, F^{\prime} =\cfrac{6 q Q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} q^{2}} \)

quest_title: If \( \left| z _ { 1 } \right| = \left| z _ { 2 } \right| \) and \( \arg \left( \cfrac { z _ { 1 } } { z _ { 2 } } \right) = \pi \) , then \( z _ { 1 } + z _ { 2 } \) is:
explanation_txt:
We have \( \arg \left( \cfrac { z _ { 1 } } { z _ { 2 } } \right) = \pi \)

\( \Rightarrow \arg \left( z _ { 1 } \right) - \arg \left( z _ { 2 } \right) = \pi \Rightarrow \arg \left( z _ { 1 } \right) = \arg \left( z _ { 2 } \right) + \pi \)

Let \(\arg \left( z _ { 2 } \right) = \theta\), then \(\arg \left( z _ { 1 } \right) = \pi + \theta\)

\( \therefore z _ { 1 } = | z _ { 1 } | [ \cos ( \pi + \theta ) + i \sin ( \pi + \theta ) ] = |z_1| (-\cos \theta - i \sin \theta ) \)

And \( z _ { 2 } = | z _ { 2 } | ( \cos \theta + i \sin \theta ) = |z_1| (\cos \theta + i \sin \theta ) \) \( ( \since |z_1| = |z_2|) \)

Hence \( z_1 + z_2 = 0 \)

quest_title: The value of \[2+\cfrac{1}{2+\cfrac{1}{2+...........\infty } } \] is
explanation_txt:
Let

\[ x = 2 + \cfrac{1}{2 + \cfrac{1}{2 + \dots \, to \, \infty}} \]

Then we can write:

\[ x = 2 + \cfrac{1}{x} \]

On simplification,

\( x^2 - 2x - 1 = 0 \\ \Rightarrow x = \cfrac{2 \pm \sqrt{4+4}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow x = 1 \pm \sqrt{2} \)

But as \(x > 0\), and \( \sqrt{2} > 1 \), \( 1- \sqrt{2} \) is discarded.

So, \(x = 1 + \sqrt{2} \)

quest_title: The maximum vertical distance that a fully dressed astronaut can jump on moon of radius \(\cfrac{1}{4}\) of earth and density \(\cfrac{2}{3}\) of earth if he can jump 1m on earth is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{e}} \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{e}}=\mathrm{mg}_{\mathrm{m}} \mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{m}}\)
or, \(\cfrac{G M_{e}}{R e^{2}} h_{e}=\cfrac{G M_{m}}{R_{m}^{2}} h_{m}\)

or, \(\cfrac{4 \pi}{3} \cfrac{R_{e}^{3} \rho_{e} h_{e}}{R_{e}^{2}}=\cfrac{4 \pi}{3} \cfrac{R_{m}^{3} \rho_{m} h_{m}}{R_{m}^{2}}\)

or, \(\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{m}}=\cfrac{R_{e} \rho_{e} h_{e}}{R_{m} h_{m}}=\cfrac{R_{e} \rho_{e} \times 1}{\cfrac{R_{e}}{4} \times \cfrac{2}{3} \rho_{e}}=6 m\)

quest_title: A convex lens of focal length 20cm is placed coaxially with diverging lens of focal length 8cm. They are at 8cm apart. An object is at very far from convex lens then position of final image is
explanation_txt:
For convex lens

\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{f}=20 \mathrm{cm}\)

For concave lens

\(\mathrm{u}=-(20-8)=-12 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{v}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fu}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{(-8) \times(-12)}{-12+8}=24 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: Two spherical conductors \(\text{A}\) and \(\text{B}\) of radii \(\text{a}\) and\(\text{b}\) (\(\text{b}\)\(\mathrm{>}\)\(\text{a}\)) are placed concentrically in air. The two are connected by a copper wire as shown in figure. Then the equivalent capacitance of the system is
explanation_txt:
In this case, charge only resides on outer surface. Hence it acts as a single sphere of radius \(b\) . So capacitance will be
\(C=4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} b\)

quest_title: The ratio of time periods of oscillation of two magnets of same moment of inertia suspended in a magnetic field is 1 : 2. The ratio of their magnetic moment is
explanation_txt:
\(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\cfrac{I}{M B}}\)
\(T'=2 \pi \sqrt{\cfrac{I}{M'B}}\)
\(\cfrac{T'}{T}=\sqrt{\cfrac{M}{M^{\prime}}}\)
\(\therefore \cfrac{M}{M^{\prime}}=\left(\cfrac{T'}{T}\right)^{2}=4: 1\)

quest_title: Which alkali metal is most metallic in character ?
explanation_txt:
\(C s > R b > K > N a > L i\)

Metallic character in decreasing order

More easily the atom loses valence electron, more metallic it is. Since size of Cs is largest among above atoms, it is most metallic.

quest_title: A solution of sodium sulphate in water is electrolyzed  using inert electrodes. The products at the cathade and anode are respectively:
explanation_txt:
When current is passed through an aqueous solution of sodium sulfate, water is oxidized at the anode and reduced at the cathode.

The equations for the reactions are given below:
Anode:
\(2 H_{2} O \rightarrow O_{2}+4 H^{+}+4 e^{-}\)
 
Cathode:
\(4 H_{2} O+4 e^{-} \rightarrow 2 H_{2}+4 O H^{-}\)
 
So, at the cathode, hydrogen is evolved and at anode, oxygen gas is evolved.

quest_title: A solution containing 98gm of \(\text{H\({}_{2}\)SO\({}_{4}\)}\) (formula wt. = 98) per litre will be
explanation_txt:
Molecular Weight of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) = 98

Concentration of H\(_2\)SO\(_4\) solution containing 98 gm of it per litre = 1 mole per litre = 1M solution = 2N Solution

Hence, the solution is molar.
question_plain_title: A solution containing 98gm of (formula wt. = 98) per litre will be
explanation_plain_text:
Molecular Weight of HSO = 98

Concentration of HSO solution containing 98 gm of it per litre = 1 mole per litre = 1M solution = 2N Solution

Hence, the solution is molar.

\( \therefore \) Greatest angle is \( 5 \pi / 9 \)

quest_title: 100 coplaner forces each equal to 10N act on a body. Each force makes and angle \(\pi /50\) with each preceeding force. The resultant force will be.
explanation_txt:
\(\text { Total angle }=\mathrm{N} \times \cfrac{\pi}{50}=100 \times \cfrac{\pi}{50}=2 \pi\)

If total angle is \(2 \pi\) then forces form a regular polygon. The resultant of (N-1) forces must be equal to either force in magnitude & opposite in direction so Reultant

R = F - F = 0
question_plain_title: 100 coplaner forces each equal to 10N act on a body. Each force makes and angle with each preceeding force. The resultant force will be.
explanation_plain_text:

R = F - F = 0

quest_title: A telescope of diameter 2\(\textit{m}\) uses light of wavelength 5000 Å for viewing stars. The minimum angular separation between two stars whose image is just resolved by this telescope is
explanation_txt:
Minimum angular separation

\(\Delta \theta =\cfrac{1.22\; \lambda }{d}=\cfrac{1.22\times 5000\times 10^{-10} }{2} =0.3\times 10^{-6} rad\)
